quiz.question: What is the safe speed requirement for vessels in restricted visibility?
quiz.truth_answer: Every vessel shall proceed at a safe speed adapted to the prevailing circumstances and conditions of restricted visibility.

(b) In construing and complying with these Rules due regard shall be had to all dangers of navigation

quiz.question: What sound signal equipment is required for a seaplane?
quiz.truth_answer: A whistle; if impracticable to show lights and shapes as prescribed, exhibit lights and shapes as closely similar in characteristics and position as possible.

rubric.criterion: Closely similar signals if impracticable to show prescribed lights/shapes

quiz.question: What is the windward vessel's obligation?
quiz.truth_answer: When both have the wind on the same side, the vessel which is to windward shall keep out of the way.

quiz.question: What is the definition of overtaking?
quiz.truth_answer: A vessel shall be deemed to be overtaking when coming up with another vessel from a direction more than 22.5 degrees abaft her beam.

quiz.question: What is the definition of 'vessel'?
quiz.truth_answer: Every description of water craft used or capable of being used as a means of transportation on water.

rubric.criterion: Correctly states vessel includes all types of watercraft
Includes craft used or capable of being used for transportation

Rule 32 Definitions (a) The word 'whistle' means any sound signalling appliance capable of producing the prescribed blasts and which complies with the specifications in Annex III to these Regulations. quiz.question: What is the windward vessel's obligation?
quiz.truth_answer: When both have the wind on the same side, the vessel which is to windward shall keep out of the way.

rubric.criterion: States vessel to windward keeps clear when both have wind on same side

Rule 12 Sailing Vessels (a) When two sailing vessels are approaching one another, so as to involve risk of collision, one of them shall keep out of the way of the other as follows; (i) when each has the wind on a different side, the vessel which has the wind on the port side shall keep out of the way of the other; (ii) when both have the wind on the same side, the vessel which is to windward shall keep out of the way

quiz.question: What is the definition of overtaking?
quiz.truth_answer: A vessel shall be deemed to be overtaking when coming up with another vessel from a direction more than 22.5 degrees abaft her beam.

quiz.question: What lights does a power-driven vessel underway show?
quiz.truth_answer: A masthead light forward, a second abaft and higher than the first, sidelights, and a sternlight.

quiz.question: What is the definition of a narrow channel?
quiz.truth_answer: A narrow channel or fairway means any part of a channel or fairway where the width between the innermost vertical lines of the lateral marks does not exceed 10% of the overall width of the channel or fairway, or does not exceed 75 metres.

rubric.criterion: Correctly defines narrow channel in terms of percentage and/or metre threshold

quiz.question: What is the definition of a narrow channel?
quiz.truth_answer: A narrow channel or fairway means any part of a channel or fairway where the width between the innermost vertical lines of the lateral marks does not exceed 10% of the overall width of the channel or fairway, or does not exceed 75 metres.

rubric.criterion: Correctly defines narrow channel in terms of percentage and/or metre threshold
States the specific numerical thresholds (10% or 75m)

Rule 32 Definitions (a) The word 'whistle' means any sound signalling appliance capable of producing the prescribed blasts and which complies with the specifications in Annex III to these Regulations. (b) The term 'short blast' means a blast of about one second's duration. (c) The term 'prolonged blast' means a blast of from four to six seconds's duration.
Rule 37 Distress Signals When a vessel is in distress and requires assistance she shall use or exhibit the signals described in Annex IV to these Regulations. PART E - EXEMPTIONS

Rule 17 Action by Stand-on Vessel (a) (i) Where one of two vessels is to keep out of the way the other shall keep her course and speed. (b) When, from any cause, the vessel requir

charge of a navigational watch shall not be as -signed or undertake any duties which would interfere with the safe navigation of the ship. [ Look-out ] 11. quiz.question: What signals indicate distress?
quiz.truth_answer: A gun fired at intervals of about a minute, continuous sounding with fog-signalling apparatus, rockets or shells throwing red stars, or radiotelegraphy signal.

rubric.criterion: Red stars from rockets or shells

supporting_quotes.quote: ANNEX IV DISTRESS SIGNALS 1. The following signals, used or exhibited either together or separately, indicate distress and need of assistance : (a) a gun or other explosive signal fired at intervals of about a minute; (b) a continuous sounding with any fog-signalling apparatus; (c) rockets or shells, throwing red stars fired one at a time at short intervals; (d) a signal made by radiotelegraphy or by any other signal

ANNEX II ADDITIONAL SIGNALS FOR FISHING VESSELS FISHING IN CLOSE PROXIMITY 1. General The lights mentioned herein shall, if exhibited in pursuance of Rule 26(d), be placed where they can best be seen. quiz.question: What sound signal does a pilot vessel make?
quiz.truth_answer: One prolonged blast at intervals not exceeding 2 minutes

rubric.criterion: Correctly identifies the signal type (prolonged blast)
Correctly states the interval frequency (not exceeding 2 minutes)

(b) A pilot vessel w

quiz.question: Do Annex I requirements apply in all weather?
quiz.truth_answer: No, only from sunset to sunrise.

rubric.criterion: States the requirement is limited to sunset-sunrise

(b) A vessel

quiz.question: What is the purpose of a proper look-out?
quiz.truth_answer: To make a full appraisal of the situation and risk of collision.

supporting_quotes.quote: Rule 12 Sailing Vessels (a) When two sailing vessels are approaching one another, so as to involve risk of collision, one of them shall keep out of the way of the other as follows; (i) when each has the wind on a different side, the vessel which has the wind on the port side shall keep out of the way of the other; (ii) when both have the wind on the same side, the vessel which is to windward shall keep out of the way

Rule 17 Action by Stand-on Vessel (a) (i) Where one of two vessels is to keep out of the way the other shall keep her course and speed. (ii) The latter vessel may however take action to avoid collision by her manoeuvre alone, as soon as it becomes apparent to her that the vessel required to keep out of the way is not taking appropriate action in compliance with these Rules. (b) When, from any cause, the vessel requir
Rule 16 Action by Give-way Vessel Every vessel which is directed to keep out of the way of another vessel shall, so far as possible, take early and substantial action to keep well clear.

charge of a navigational watch shall not be as -signed or undertake any duties which would interfere with the safe navigation of the ship. [ Look-out ] 11. Every ship shall at all times maintain a proper look -out by sight and hearing as well as by all available means appropriate in the prevailing circumstances and conditions so as to make a full appraisal of the situation and of the risk of collision, stranding and

Rule 5 Look-out Every vessel shall at all times maintain a proper look-out by sight and hearing as well as by all available means appropriate in the prevailing circumstances and conditions so as to make a full appraisal of the situation and of the risk of collision.

quiz.question: What is the windward vessel's obligation?
quiz.truth_answer: When both have the wind on the same side, the vessel which is to windward shall keep out of the way.

rubric.criterion: States vessel to windward keeps clear when both have wind on same side

quiz.title: A vessel restricted in her ability to manoeuvre when at anchor - lights
quiz.scenario: Type of vessel: Vessel restricted in her ability to manoeuvre of more than 100 m in length when at anchor Time of the day: From sunset to sunrise and from sunrise to sunset in restricted visibility
quiz.reference_application: In accordance with Rule 27 (b) (Vessels not under command or restricted in their ability to manoeuvre), a vessel restricted in her ability to manoeuvre , except a vessel engaged in mine clearance operations, shall exhibit: (i) three all-round lights in a vertical line where they can best be seen. The highest and lowest of these lights shall be red and the middle light shall be white; (iv) the light or lights prescribed in Rule 30 (Anchored vessels and vessels aground). In accordance with Rule 30 (a) (Anchored vessels and vessels aground), a vessel at anchor shall exhibit where it can best be seen: (i) in the fore part, an all-round white light; (ii) at or near the stern and at a lower level that the light prescribed in subparagraph (i), an all-round white light. In accordance with Rule 30 (c) (Anchored vessels and vessels aground), a vessel of 100 m and more in length at anchor shall, also use the available working or equivalent lights to illuminate her decks.

quiz.question: A seaplane on the water must:
choices: Keep well clear of all vessels
Keep distance from sailing vessels only

quiz.title: Relative bearing of overtaking vessel is PORT 130°
quiz.scenario: Vessel A: power-driven vessel Vessel B: power-driven vessel Area: On the high seas Visibility: Good (Vessels in sight of one another) Vessel A is overtaking vessel B Vessel B has vessel A on her own port side (relative bearing PORT 130°)
quiz.reference_application: In accordance with Rule 13 (b) (Overtaking), vessel A shall be deemed to be overtaking vessel B because she is coming up with vessel B from a direction more than 22.5° abaft her beam. In accordance with Rule 13 (b) (Overtaking), vessel A is in such a position with reference to the vessel she is overtaking (vessel B), that at night she (vessel A) would be able to see only the sternlight of vessel B but neither of her sidelights . In accordance with Rule 13 (a) (Overtaking), notwithstanding anything contained in the Rules of part B, sections I and II, any vessel overtaking (vessel A) any other (vessel B) shall keep out of the way of the vessel being overtaken (vessel B).

quiz.question: A vessel which is being overtaken shall not alter course to:
When the length of a tow exceeds 200 metres, the towing vessel shall exhibit:
choices: Two masthead lights in a vertical line
Three masthead lights in a vertical line
Four masthead lights in a vertical line

quiz.title: A WIG craft when taking off, landing and in flight near the surface - lights
quiz.scenario: Type of vessel: WIG craft Time of the day: From sunset to sunrise and from sunrise to sunset in restricted visibility
quiz.reference_application: In accordance with Rule 23 (c) (Power-driven vessels underway ), a WIG craft only when taking off, landing and in flight near the surface shall, in addition to the lights prescribed in Rule 23 (a) (Power-driven vessels underway ), exhibit a high intensity all-round flashing red light.

quiz.title: Crossing situation (relative bearing STBD 070°) - making 360° turn to starboard
quiz.scenario: Vessel A: power-driven vessel Vessel B: power-driven vessel Area: On the high seas Visibility: Good (Vessels in sight of one another) Vessel A has vessel B on her own starboard side (relative bearing STBD 070°) Vessel A and vessel B are crossing so as to involve risk of collision Vessel A is making 360° turn to starboard to avoid collision with vessel B
quiz.reference_application: In accordance with Rule 15 (Crossing situation), when two power-driven vessels are crossing so as to involve risk of collision , the vessel (vessel A) which has the other (vessel B) on her own starboard side shall keep out of the way. In accordance with Rule 15 (Crossing situation), vessel A shall, if the circumstances of the case admit, avoid crossing ahead of vessel B. In accordance with Rule 16 (Action by give-way vessel), every vessel (vessel A) which is directed to keep out of the way of another vessel (vessel B) shall, so far as possible, take early and substantial action to keep well clear.

In accordance with Rule 15 (Crossing situation), vessel A shall, if the circumstances of the case admit, avoid crossing ahead of vessel B. quiz.title: Sound signals when altering course to starboard
quiz.scenario: Vessel A: Power-driven vessel underway , when manoeuvring Vessels are in sight of one another
quiz.reference_application: In accordance with Rule 34 (a) (Manoeuvring and warning signals), a vessel altering its course to starboard (vessel A) shall indicate that manoeuvre by one short blast on her whistle . In accordance with Rule 34 (f) (Manoeuvring and warning signals), if whistles are fitted on a vessel at a distance apart of more than 100 m, one whistle only shall be used for giving manoeuvring and warning signals.

quiz.title: Sound signals and supplemental light signals when operating astern propulsion
quiz.scenario: Vessel A: Power-driven vessel underway , when manoeuvring Vessels are in sight of one another
quiz.reference_application: In accordance with Rule 34 (a) (Manoeuvring and warning signals), a vessel operating astern propulsion (vessel A) shall indicate that manoeuvre by three short blasts on her whistle . In accordance with Rule 34 (b)(i) (Manoeuvring and warning signals), a vessel operating astern propulsion (vessel A) may supplement the whistle signals prescribed in Rule 34 (a) (Manoeuvring and warning signals) by light signals and indicate that manoeuvre by three flashes. In accordance with Rule 34 (b)(ii) (Manoeuvring and warning signals), the duration of each flash shall be about one second, the interval between flashes shall be about one second, and the interval between successive signals shall be not less that ten seconds. In accordance with Rule 34 (b)(iii) (Manoeuvring and warning signals), the light used for this signal shall, if fitted, be an all-round white light, visible at a minimum range of 5 miles, and shall comply with the provisions of Annex I to these Regulations. In accordance with Rule 34 (f) (Manoeuvring and warning signals), if whistles are fitted on a vessel at a distance apart of more than 100 m, one whistle only shall be used for giving manoeuvring and warning signals.

supporting_quotes.quote: Rule 14 Head-on Situation (a) When two power-driven vessels are meeting on reciprocal or nearly reciprocal courses so as to involve risk of collision each shall alter her course to starboard so that each shall pass on the port side of the other. (b) Such a situation shall be deemed to exist when a vessel sees the other ahead or nearly ahead and by night she could see the masthead lights of the other in a line or near

Rule 5 Look-out Every vessel shall at all times maintain a proper look-out by sight and hearing as well as by all available means appropriate in the prevailing circumstances and conditions so as to make a full appraisal of the situation and of the risk of collision.

RULE 19 Conduct of Vessels in Restricted Visibility (a) This Rule applies to vessels not in sight of one another when navigating in or near an area of restricted visibility. (b) Every vessel shall proceed at a safe speed adapted to the prevailing circumstances and conditions of restricted visibility. A power-driven vessel shall have engines ready for immediate manoeuvre. (c) Every vessel shall have due regard to the

Rule 8 Action to avoid Collision (A amended paragraph (a) shall enter into force on 29 November 2003, as amended by Resolution A.919(22)) (a) Any action to avoid collision shall be taken in accordance with the Rules of this Part and shall, if the circumstances of the case admit, be positive, made in ample time and with due regard to the observance of good seamanship. (b) Any alteration of course and/or speed to avoid

Rule 15 Crossing Situation When two power-driven vessels are crossing so as to involve risk of collision, the vessel which has the other on her own starboard side shall keep out of the way and shall, if the circumstances of the case admit, avoid crossing ahead of the other vessel.

Rule 7 Risk of Collision (a) Every vessel shall use all available means appropriate to the prevailing circumstances and conditions to determine if risk of collision exists. If there is any doubt such risk shall be deemed to exist. (b) Proper use shall be made of radar equipment if fitted and operational, including long-range scanning to obtain early warning of risk of collision and radar plotting or equivalent system

quiz.reference_application: In accordance with Rule 25 (c) (Sailings vessels underway and vessels under oars), a sailing vessel underway may, in addition to the lights prescribed in Rule 25 (a) (Sailings vessels underway and vessels under oars) exhibit at or near the top of the mast, where they can best be seen, two all-round lights in a vertical line, the upper being red and the lower green, but these lights shall not be exhibited in conjunction with the combined lantern permitted by Rule 25 (b) (Sailings vessels underway and vessels under oars).

quiz.scenario: Vessel A: Power-driven vessel Vessel B: Power-driven vessel Area: On the high seas Visibility: Good (Vessels in sight of one another) Vessel A and vessel B are crossing so as to involve risk of collision Vessel A has vessel B on her own starboard side (relative bearing STBD 054°)
quiz.reference_application: In accordance with Rule 15 (Crossing situation), when two power-driven vessels are crossing so as to involve risk of collision , the vessel (vessel A) which has the other (vessel B) on her own starboard side shall keep out of the way. In accordance with Rule 15 (Crossing situation), vessel A shall, if the circumstances of the case admit, avoid crossing ahead of the vessel B.

quiz.title: Sound signals when altering course to starboard
quiz.scenario: Vessel A: Power-driven vessel underway , when manoeuvring Vessels are in sight of one another
quiz.reference_application: In accordance with Rule 34 (a) (Manoeuvring and warning signals), a vessel altering its course to starboard (vessel A) shall indicate that manoeuvre by one short blast on her whistle . In accordance with Rule 34 (f) (Manoeuvring and warning signals), if whistles are fitted on a vessel at a distance apart of more than 100 m, one whistle only shall be used for giving manoeuvring and warning signals.

quiz.title: Sound signals and supplemental light signals when operating astern propulsion
quiz.scenario: Vessel A: Power-driven vessel underway , when manoeuvring Vessels are in sight of one another
quiz.reference_application: In accordance with Rule 34 (a) (Manoeuvring and warning signals), a vessel operating astern propulsion (vessel A) shall indicate that manoeuvre by three short blasts on her whistle . In accordance with Rule 34 (b)(i) (Manoeuvring and warning signals), a vessel operating astern propulsion (vessel A) may supplement the whistle signals prescribed in Rule 34 (a) (Manoeuvring and warning signals) by light signals and indicate that manoeuvre by three flashes. In accordance with Rule 34 (b)(ii) (Manoeuvring and warning signals), the duration of each flash shall be about one second, the interval between flashes shall be about one second, and the interval between successive signals shall be not less that ten seconds. In accordance with Rule 34 (b)(iii) (Manoeuvring and warning signals), the light used for this signal shall, if fitted, be an all-round white light, visible at a minimum range of 5 miles, and shall comply with the provisions of Annex I to these Regulations. In accordance with Rule 34 (f) (Manoeuvring and warning signals), if whistles are fitted on a vessel at a distance apart of more than 100 m, one whistle only shall be used for giving manoeuvring and warning signals.

quiz.question: What is the definition of a narrow channel?

Rule 15 Crossing Situation When two power-driven vessels are crossing so as to involve risk of collision, the vessel which has the other on her own starboard side shall keep out of the way and shall, if the circumstances of the case admit, avoid crossing ahead of the other vessel.

Rule 7 Risk of Collision (a) Every vessel shall use all available means appropriate to the prevailing circumstances and conditions to determine if risk of collision exists. quiz.title: Sound signals when altering course to starboard

quiz.reference_application: In accordance with Rule 34 (a) (Manoeuvring and warning signals), a vessel altering its course to starboard (vessel A) shall indicate that manoeuvre by one short blast on her whistle . In accordance with Rule 34 (f) (Manoeuvring and warning signals), if whistles are fitted on a vessel at a distance apart of more than 100 m, one whistle only shall be used for giving manoeuvring and warning signals.

quiz.title: Sound signals and supplemental light signals when operating astern propulsion
quiz.scenario: Vessel A: Power-driven vessel underway , when manoeuvring Vessels are in sight of one another
quiz.reference_application: In accordance with Rule 34 (a) (Manoeuvring and warning signals), a vessel operating astern propulsion (vessel A) shall indicate that manoeuvre by three short blasts on her whistle . In accordance with Rule 34 (b)(i) (Manoeuvring and warning signals), a vessel operating astern propulsion (vessel A) may supplement the whistle signals prescribed in Rule 34 (a) (Manoeuvring and warning signals) by light signals and indicate that manoeuvre by three flashes. In accordance with Rule 34 (b)(ii) (Manoeuvring and warning signals), the duration of each flash shall be about one second, the interval between flashes shall be about one second, and the interval between successive signals shall be not less that ten seconds. In accordance with Rule 34 (b)(iii) (Manoeuvring and warning signals), the light used for this signal shall, if fitted, be an all-round white light, visible at a minimum range of 5 miles, and shall comply with the provisions of Annex I to these Regulations. In accordance with Rule 34 (f) (Manoeuvring and warning signals), if whistles are fitted on a vessel at a distance apart of more than 100 m, one whistle only shall be used for giving manoeuvring and warning signals.

Rule 5 Look-out Every vessel shall at all times maintain a proper look-out by sight and hearing as well as by all available means appropriate in the prevailing circumstances and conditions so as to make a full appraisal of the situation and of the risk of collision.

RULE 19 Conduct of Vessels in Restricted Visibility (a) This Rule applies to vessels not in sight of one another when navigating in or near an area of restricted visibility. (b) Every vessel shall proceed at a safe speed adapted to the prevailing circumstances and conditions of restricted visibility. A power-driven vessel shall have engines ready for immediate manoeuvre. (c) Every vessel shall have due regard to the

Rule 8 Action to avoid Collision (A amended paragraph (a) shall enter into force on 29 November 2003, as amended by Resolution A.919(22)) (a) Any action to avoid collision shall be taken in accordance with the Rules of this Part and shall, if the circumstances of the case admit, be positive, made in ample time and with due regard to the observance of good seamanship. (b) Any alteration of course and/or speed to avoid

Rule 15 Crossing Situation When two power-driven vessels are crossing so as to involve risk of collision, the vessel which has the other on her own starboard side shall keep out of the way and shall, if the circumstances of the case admit, avoid crossing ahead of the other vessel.

Rule 7 Risk of Collision (a) Every vessel shall use all available means appropriate to the prevailing circumstances and conditions to determine if risk of collision exists. If there is any doubt such risk shall be deemed to exist. (b) Proper use shall be made of radar equipment if fitted and operational, including long-range scanning to obtain early warning of risk of collision and radar plotting or equivalent system

quiz.title: A sailing vessel underway - additional two all-round lights
quiz.scenario: Type of vessel: Sailing vessel underway Time of the day: From sunset to sunrise and from sunrise to sunset in restricted visibility
quiz.reference_application: In accordance with Rule 25 (c) (Sailings vessels underway and vessels under oars), a sailing vessel underway may, in addition to the lights prescribed in Rule 25 (a) (Sailings vessels underway and vessels under oars) exhibit at or near the top of the mast, where they can best be seen, two all-round lights in a vertical line, the upper being red and the lower green, but these lights shall not be exhibited in conjunction with the combined lantern permitted by Rule 25 (b) (Sailings vessels underway and vessels under oars).

quiz.title: Vessel A has vessel B on her own starboard side (relative bearing STBD 054°)
quiz.scenario: Vessel A: Power-driven vessel Vessel B: Power-driven vessel Area: On the high seas Visibility: Good (Vessels in sight of one another) Vessel A and vessel B are crossing so as to involve risk of collision Vessel A has vessel B on her own starboard side (relative bearing STBD 054°)
quiz.reference_application: In accordance with Rule 15 (Crossing situation), when two power-driven vessels are crossing so as to involve risk of collision , the vessel (vessel A) which has the other (vessel B) on her own starboard side shall keep out of the way. In accordance with Rule 15 (Crossing situation), vessel A shall, if the circumstances of the case admit, avoid crossing ahead of the vessel B.

quiz.title: Sound signals when altering course to starboard
quiz.scenario: Vessel A: Power-driven vessel underway , when manoeuvring Vessels are in sight of one another
quiz.reference_application: In accordance with Rule 34 (a) (Manoeuvring and warning signals), a vessel altering its course to starboard (vessel A) shall indicate that manoeuvre by one short blast on her whistle . In accordance with Rule 34 (f) (Manoeuvring and warning signals), if whistles are fitted on a vessel at a distance apart of more than 100 m, one whistle only shall be used for giving manoeuvring and warning signals.

quiz.title: Sound signals and supplemental light signals when operating astern propulsion
quiz.scenario: Vessel A: Power-driven vessel underway , when manoeuvring Vessels are in sight of one another
quiz.reference_application: In accordance with Rule 34 (a) (Manoeuvring and warning signals), a vessel operating astern propulsion (vessel A) shall indicate that manoeuvre by three short blasts on her whistle . In accordance with Rule 34 (b)(i) (Manoeuvring and warning signals), a vessel operating astern propulsion (vessel A) may supplement the whistle signals prescribed in Rule 34 (a) (Manoeuvring and warning signals) by light signals and indicate that manoeuvre by three flashes. In accordance with Rule 34 (b)(ii) (Manoeuvring and warning signals), the duration of each flash shall be about one second, the interval between flashes shall be about one second, and the interval between successive signals shall be not less that ten seconds. In accordance with Rule 34 (b)(iii) (Manoeuvring and warning signals), the light used for this signal shall, if fitted, be an all-round white light, visible at a minimum range of 5 miles, and shall comply with the provisions of Annex I to these Regulations. In accordance with Rule 34 (f) (Manoeuvring and warning signals), if whistles are fitted on a vessel at a distance apart of more than 100 m, one whistle only shall be used for giving manoeuvring and warning signals.

quiz.question: What is the definition of a narrow channel?
quiz.truth_answer: A narrow channel or fairway means any part of a channel or fairway where the width between the innermost vertical lines of the lateral marks does not exceed 10% of the overall width of the channel or fairway, or does not exceed 75 metres.

Rule 5 Look-out Every vessel shall at all times maintain a proper look-out by sight and hearing as well as by all available means appropriate in the prevailing circumstances and conditions so as to make a full appraisal of the situation and of the risk of collision.

RULE 19 Conduct of Vessels in Restricted Visibility (a) This Rule applies to vessels not in sight of one another when navigating in or near an area of restricted visibility. (c) Every vessel shall have due regard to the

Rule 8 Action to avoid Collision (A amended paragraph (a) shall enter into force on 29 November 2003, as amended by Resolution A.919(22)) (a) Any action to avoid collision shall be taken in accordance with the Rules of this Part and shall, if the circumstances of the case admit, be positive, made in ample time and with due regard to the observance of good seamanship. (b) Any alteration of course and/or speed to avoid

Rule 15 Crossing Situation When two power-driven vessels are crossing so as to involve risk of collision, the vessel which has the other on her own starboard side shall keep out of the way and shall, if the circumstances of the case admit, avoid crossing ahead of the other vessel.

Rule 7 Risk of Collision (a) Every vessel shall use all available means appropriate to the prevailing circumstances and conditions to determine if risk of collision exists. quiz.title: A sailing vessel underway - additional two all-round lights
quiz.scenario: Type of vessel: Sailing vessel underway Time of the day: From sunset to sunrise and from sunrise to sunset in restricted visibility
quiz.reference_application: In accordance with Rule 25 (c) (Sailings vessels underway and vessels under oars), a sailing vessel underway may, in addition to the lights prescribed in Rule 25 (a) (Sailings vessels underway and vessels under oars) exhibit at or near the top of the mast, where they can best be seen, two all-round lights in a vertical line, the upper being red and the lower green, but these lights shall not be exhibited in conjunction with the combined lantern permitted by Rule 25 (b) (Sailings vessels underway and vessels under oars).

quiz.title: Vessel A has vessel B on her own starboard side (relative bearing STBD 054°)
quiz.scenario: Vessel A: Power-driven vessel Vessel B: Power-driven vessel Area: On the high seas Visibility: Good (Vessels in sight of one another) Vessel A and vessel B are crossing so as to involve risk of collision Vessel A has vessel B on her own starboard side (relative bearing STBD 054°)
quiz.reference_application: In accordance with Rule 15 (Crossing situation), when two power-driven vessels are crossing so as to involve risk of collision , the vessel (vessel A) which has the other (vessel B) on her own starboard side shall keep out of the way. In accordance with Rule 15 (Crossing situation), vessel A shall, if the circumstances of the case admit, avoid crossing ahead of the vessel B.

quiz.title: Sound signals when altering course to starboard
quiz.scenario: Vessel A: Power-driven vessel underway , when manoeuvring Vessels are in sight of one another
quiz.reference_application: In accordance with Rule 34 (a) (Manoeuvring and warning signals), a vessel altering its course to starboard (vessel A) shall indicate that manoeuvre by one short blast on her whistle . In accordance with Rule 34 (f) (Manoeuvring and warning signals), if whistles are fitted on a vessel at a distance apart of more than 100 m, one whistle only shall be used for giving manoeuvring and warning signals.

quiz.title: Sound signals and supplemental light signals when operating astern propulsion
quiz.scenario: Vessel A: Power-driven vessel underway , when manoeuvring Vessels are in sight of one another
quiz.reference_application: In accordance with Rule 34 (a) (Manoeuvring and warning signals), a vessel operating astern propulsion (vessel A) shall indicate that manoeuvre by three short blasts on her whistle . In accordance with Rule 34 (b)(i) (Manoeuvring and warning signals), a vessel operating astern propulsion (vessel A) may supplement the whistle signals prescribed in Rule 34 (a) (Manoeuvring and warning signals) by light signals and indicate that manoeuvre by three flashes. In accordance with Rule 34 (b)(ii) (Manoeuvring and warning signals), the duration of each flash shall be about one second, the interval between flashes shall be about one second, and the interval between successive signals shall be not less that ten seconds. In accordance with Rule 34 (b)(iii) (Manoeuvring and warning signals), the light used for this signal shall, if fitted, be an all-round white light, visible at a minimum range of 5 miles, and shall comply with the provisions of Annex I to these Regulations. In accordance with Rule 34 (f) (Manoeuvring and warning signals), if whistles are fitted on a vessel at a distance apart of more than 100 m, one whistle only shall be used for giving manoeuvring and warning signals.

quiz.title: A power-driven vessel under 12 m underway - displaced lights
quiz.scenario: Type of vessel: Power-driven vessel of less than 12 m in length underway Time of the day: From sunset to sunrise and from sunrise to sunset in restricted visibility
quiz.reference_application: In accordance with Rule 23 (d)(iii) (Power-driven vessels underway ), the masthead light or all-round white light on a power driven vessel of less than 12 m in length may be displaced from the fore and aft centerline of the vessel if centerline fitting is not practicable, provided the sidelights are combined in one lantern which shall be carried on the fore and aft centerline of the vessel or located as nearly as practicable in the same fore and aft line as the masthead light or all-round white light.

quiz.question: What sound signal does a vessel engaged on pilotage duty use to identify itself?

quiz.title: A vessel engaged in trawling when making way through the water - lights
quiz.scenario: Type of vessel: Vessel engaged in trawling when making way through the water Time of the day: From sunset to sunrise and from sunrise to sunset in restricted visibility
quiz.reference_application: In accordance with Rule 26 (a) (Fishing vessels), a vessel engaged in fishing , whether underway or at anchor, shall exhibit only the lights and shapes prescribed in Rule 26 (Fishing vessels). In accordance with Rule 26 (b) (Fishing vessels), a vessel when engaged in trawling, by which is meant the dragging through the water of a dredge net or other apparatus used as a fishing appliance, shall exhibit: (i) two all-round lights in a vertical line, the upper being green and the lower white; (ii) a masthead light abaft of and higher that the all-round green light; (iii) sidelights and a sternlight . In accordance with Rule 26 (b) (ii) (Fishing vessels), a vessel of less than 50 metres in length shall not be obliged to exhibit a masthead light but may do so.

quiz.question: The forward masthead light must be placed at least how many meters above the hull for vessels 20 meters or more?

quiz.title: Sound signals in narrow channel or fairway to indicate intention to overtake another vessel on her port side
quiz.scenario: Vessel A: Vessel about to be overtaken Vessel B: Vessel intending to overtake another vessel Area: Narrow channel of fairway Vessels are in sight of one another
quiz.reference_application: In accordance with Rule 34 (c)(i) (Manoeuvring and warning signals), when in sight of one another in a narrow channel or fairway a vessel intending to overtake (vessel B) another vessel (vessel A) on her port side shall in compliance with Rule 9 (e)(i) ( Narrow Channels ) indicate her intention by two prolonged blasts followed by two short blasts on her whistle . In accordance with Rule 34 (c)(ii) (Manoeuvring and warning signals), the vessel about to be overtaken (vessel A) when acting in accordance with Rule 9 (e)(i) ( Narrow Channels ) shall indicate her agreement by one prolonged, one short, one prolonged and one short blast on her whistle , in that order. In accordance with Rule 34 (f) (Manoeuvring and warning signals), if whistles are fitted on a vessel at a distance apart of more than 100 m, one whistle only shall be used for giving manoeuvring and warning signals.

quiz.reference_application: In accordance with Rule 23 (d)(iii) (Power-driven vessels underway ), the masthead light or all-round white light on a power driven vessel of less than 12 m in length may be displaced from the fore and aft centerline of the vessel if centerline fitting is not practicable, provided the sidelights are combined in one lantern which shall be carried on the fore and aft centerline of the vessel or located as nearly as practicable in the same fore and aft line as the masthead light or all-round white light.

quiz.title: A WIG craft
quiz.scenario: Type of vessel: WIG craft
quiz.reference_application: In accordance with Rule 31 (Seaplanes), where it is impracticable for a WIG craft to exhibit lights and shapes of the characteristics or in the positions prescribed in the Rules of this Part she shall exhibit lights and shapes as closely similar in characteristics and position as is possible.

quiz.question: What sound signal does a vessel engaged on pilotage duty use to identify itself?

quiz.title: A vessel engaged in trawling when making way through the water - lights
quiz.scenario: Type of vessel: Vessel engaged in trawling when making way through the water Time of the day: From sunset to sunrise and from sunrise to sunset in restricted visibility
quiz.reference_application: In accordance with Rule 26 (a) (Fishing vessels), a vessel engaged in fishing , whether underway or at anchor, shall exhibit only the lights and shapes prescribed in Rule 26 (Fishing vessels). In accordance with Rule 26 (b) (Fishing vessels), a vessel when engaged in trawling, by which is meant the dragging through the water of a dredge net or other apparatus used as a fishing appliance, shall exhibit: (i) two all-round lights in a vertical line, the upper being green and the lower white; (ii) a masthead light abaft of and higher that the all-round green light; (iii) sidelights and a sternlight . In accordance with Rule 26 (b) (ii) (Fishing vessels), a vessel of less than 50 metres in length shall not be obliged to exhibit a masthead light but may do so.

quiz.question: The forward masthead light must be placed at least how many meters above the hull for vessels 20 meters or more?

quiz.title: Sound signals in narrow channel or fairway to indicate intention to overtake another vessel on her port side
quiz.scenario: Vessel A: Vessel about to be overtaken Vessel B: Vessel intending to overtake another vessel Area: Narrow channel of fairway Vessels are in sight of one another
quiz.reference_application: In accordance with Rule 34 (c)(i) (Manoeuvring and warning signals), when in sight of one another in a narrow channel or fairway a vessel intending to overtake (vessel B) another vessel (vessel A) on her port side shall in compliance with Rule 9 (e)(i) ( Narrow Channels ) indicate her intention by two prolonged blasts followed by two short blasts on her whistle . In accordance with Rule 34 (c)(ii) (Manoeuvring and warning signals), the vessel about to be overtaken (vessel A) when acting in accordance with Rule 9 (e)(i) ( Narrow Channels ) shall indicate her agreement by one prolonged, one short, one prolonged and one short blast on her whistle , in that order. In accordance with Rule 34 (f) (Manoeuvring and warning signals), if whistles are fitted on a vessel at a distance apart of more than 100 m, one whistle only shall be used for giving manoeuvring and warning signals.
